  techniques_name: gilding (technique) forging (metal forming)

  physical_appearance: This necklace features a thick chain with a large central pendant that is inset with several gemstones. At the bottom of the pendant
 there are several beads attached. The main chain of the necklace where the pendant is attached to has a butterfly link chain
 that is also inset with gemstones.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan cultural diffusion

  subject_terms_2: Culture diffusion Peranakan (Asian people) Jewelry Intermarriage Necklaces

  subject_terms_3: Jewellery Peranakan costumes

  sgcool_label_text: The necklace is made of gilded silver and features a large central pendant inset with gemstones
 with beads at the bottom of the pendant. The pendant is attached to the main chain of the necklace with a butterfly decoration similarly set with gemstones. They were often crafted by Indian goldsmiths. The intricacy of the patterns and designs were closely associated with the financial and social status of the wearer.  Although commonly used in China to prevent tarnishing
 the practice of gilding silver did not become popular in India.  Peranakan Indians were descended from marriages between South Indian Hindu merchants and local inhabitants.

metadata.physical_appearance: This necklace features a thick chain with a large central pendant that is inset with several gemstones. At the bottom of the pendant, there are several beads attached. The main chain of the necklace where the pendant is attached to has a butterfly link chain, that is also inset with gemstones.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Culture diffusion Peranakan (Asian people) Jewelry Intermarriage Necklaces
metadata.sgcool_label_text: The necklace is made of gilded silver and features a large central pendant inset with gemstones, with beads at the bottom of the pendant. The pendant is attached to the main chain of the necklace with a butterfly decoration similarly set with gemstones. They were often crafted by Indian goldsmiths. The intricacy of the patterns and designs were closely associated with the financial and social status of the wearer.  Although commonly used in China to prevent tarnishing, the practice of gilding silver did not become popular in India.  Peranakan Indians were descended from marriages between South Indian Hindu merchants and local inhabitants.
